p.seg: The Master said:
“Having studied,1 to then repeatedly apply what you have learned—
is this not a source of pleasure?
To have friends come from distant quarters2—
is this not a source of enjoyment?
To go unacknowledged by others without harboring frustration—
is this not the markof an exemplary person (junzi )?
Master You3 said:
“It is a rare thing for someonewho has a sense of filial and fraternal responsibility (xiaodi ) to have a taste for defying authority.
And it is unheard of for those who have no taste for defying authority to be keen on initiating rebellion.
Exemplary persons (junzi) concentrate their efforts on the root,
for the root having taken hold, the way (dao ) will grow therefrom.
As for filial and fraternal responsibility,
it is, I suspect, the root of authoritative conduct(ren ).”4
The Master said:
“It is a rare thing for glib speechand an insinuating appearance
to accompany authoritative conduct (ren ).”5
Master Zeng said:
“Daily I examine my person onthree counts.
In my undertakings on behalf of other people, have I failed to do my utmost (zhong)?
In my interactions with colleagues and friends,have I failed to make good on my word (xin )?
Inwhat has been passed on to me, have I failed tocarry it into practice?”
The Master said:
“The way (dao ) to lead a thousand-chariot state
effectively is to carry out your official duties respectfully and make good onyour word (xin );
be frugal in your expenditures and love your peers;
and put the common peopleto work only at the proper time of year.”6
The Master said:
“As a younger brother and son,
be 􀉹lial (xiao ) at home
and deferential (di ) inthe community;
be cautious in what you say andthen make good on your word (xin );
love themultitude broadly and be intimate with those whoare authoritative in their conduct (ren ).7
If in sobehaving you still have energy left,
use it toimprove yourself through study.”
Zixia8 said:
“As for persons who care for charactermuch more than beauty,
who in serving theirparents are able to exert themselves utterly,
whogive their whole person in the service of theirruler,
and who, in interactions with colleagues andfriends, make good on their word (xin )—
even ifit were said of such persons that they areunschooled,
I would insist that they are welleducated indeed.”
The Master said:
“Exemplary persons (junzi )lacking in gravity would have no dignity.
Yet intheir studies they are not in􀉻exible.9
Take doingyour utmost and making good on your word (xin) as your mainstay.
Do not have as a friendanyone who is not as good as you are.10
Andwhere you have erred, do not hesitate to mendyour ways.”
Master Zeng said:
“Be circumspect in funeraryservices
and continue sacri􀉹ces to the distantancestors,
and the virtue (de ) of the commonpeople will thrive.”11
Ziqin asked Zigong:12
“When the Master arrives ina particular state
and needs to learn how it is being governed,
does he seek out this information
or is it offered to him?”
Zigong replied:
“The Master gets all he needs by being cordial, proper, deferential, frugal, and unassuming.
Perhaps this way of seeking information
is somewhat different from how others go about it.”
The Master said:
“While a person’s father is still alive,
observe what he intends;
when his father dies,
observe what he does.13
A person who for three years refrains from reforming14 the ways(dao ) of his late father
can be called a filial son(xiao ).”15
Master You said:
“Achieving harmony (he ) is the most valuable function of observing ritual propriety (li ).
In the ways of the Former Kings,
this achievement of harmony made them elegant,
and was a guiding standard in all things large and small.
But when things are not going well,
to realize harmony just for its own sake
without regulating the situation through observing ritual propriety
will not work.”16
Master You said:
“That making good on one’s word(xin ) gets one close to being appropriate (yi )
is because then what one says will bear repeating.
That being deferential gets one close to observing ritual propriety (li )
is because it keeps disgrace and insult at a distance.
Those who are accommodating and do not lose those with whom they
are close are deserving of esteem.”
The Master said:
“In eating, exemplary persons(junzi ) do not look for a full stomach,
nor in their lodgings for comfort and contentment.
They are persons of action yet cautious in what they say.
They repair to those who know the way (dao), and 􀉹nd improvement in their company.
Suchpersons can indeed be said to have a love of learning (haoxue ).”
Zigong said:
“What do you think of the saying: ‘Poor but not inferior;
The Master replied:
rich but not superior’?”
“Not bad,
but not as good as: ‘Poor but enjoying the way (dao );18
rich but lovingritual propriety (li )’ ”
Zigong said:
“The Book of Songs states:
Like bone carved and polished,
Like jade cut and ground.19
Is this not what you have in mind?”
The Master said:
“Zigong,
it is only with thelikes of you then that I can discuss the Songs!
Onthe basis of what has been said, you know what isyet to come.”
The Master said:
“Don’t worry about not beingacknowledged by others;
worry about failing toacknowledge them.”
Zigong said, “I do not want others to impose on me,
nor do I want to impose on others.”
Confucius replied,
“Zigong,
this is quite beyond your reach.”
The Master said:
“Zilu,35
shall I teach you what wisdom (zhi ) means?”
To know (zhi ) what you know
and know what you do not know

—this then is wisdom.” 【We follow the Dingzhou text here. Analternative reading found in the received text wouldbe:The Master said: “Zilu, shall I instruct youin what it means to know something? Toknow what you know and know what youdo not know—this then is what it meansto know.”】

【Here we follow the Dingzhou text which has“to be accomplished in, to specialize in (gong )”rather than “to attack (gong )” as found in thereceived editions. Because the character gong “toattack” appears three other times in the Analects andin each case means “to attack,” Yang Bojun, ignoringthe fact that gong here is followed by theprepositional particle “in hu ( ),” rejects thecommentaries that would read this as “to pursue studyin.” He reads this passage as “If one attacks heterodoxdoctrines, it will put an end to their harm.” TheDingzhou text seems to resolve this debate.】

【The character shan is formulaicallytranslated as “good,” but importantly it is 􀉹rst arelational term and only derivatively an essentialattribute. It means “good at, good to, good with, goodfor, good in,” and so on, and hence, “adeptness,e􀉽caciousness, competency.” In this passage, “thosewho are adept” stand in contrast to “those who arenot (buneng ).”】
